generic: Meningococcal Vaccine, Tetanus Toxoid Conjugate Quadrivalent
drugs: Meningococcal Vaccine, Tetanus Toxoid Conjugate Quadrivalent

0.title: Generic Names
0.mono: Meningococcal Vaccine, Tetanus Toxoid Conjugate Quadrivalent

0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• meningococcal group A, C, W-135, and Y conjugate vaccine has centralized marketing authorization by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) for use in the European Union (EU)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: 0.5 mL IM as a single dose (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• meningococcal group A, C, W-135, and Y conjugate vaccine has centralized marketing authorization by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) for use in the European Union (EU)
  • safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients younger than 12 months
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (12 months or older) 0.5 mL IM as a single dose (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to Neisseria meningitidis group A, C, W-135, or Y polysaccharide, tetanus toxoid carrier protein, or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• anaphylaxis may occur following administration
  • coagulation disorders, including thrombocytopenia; bleeding may occur following IM administration
  • febrile illness, acute and severe; delay vaccine administration
  • immunodeficient or receiving immunosuppressive therapy; inadequate immune response to vaccine may occur
  • meningococcal infection, increased susceptibility due to conditions such as terminal complement deficiencies and anatomic or functional asplenia; inadequate immune response to vaccine may occur
  • syncope, in some cases with neurological signs, including transient visual disturbance, paraesthesia, and tonic-clonic limb movements, may occur, especially as a psychogenic response to needle injection in adolescents
  • tetanus vaccine; Nimenrix is not a substitute for the tetanus vaccine
  • waning of MenA antibodies, rapid, has been reported at 12 months postdose and onward; consider administration of a second dose in patients at risk of exposure to MenA

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site (14.3% to 33%), Injection site pain (24.1% to 39.9%), Swelling at injection site (11.2% to 17.9%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Loss of appetite (10% or greater)
  • Neurologic:Headache (10% or greater), Somnolence (10% or greater)
  • Psychiatric:Irritability (10% or greater)
  • Other:Fatigue (10% or greater), Fever (4% to 17.6%)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    IM use only; do not administer intravascularly, intradermally, or subQ
  • Intramuscular
    • refrigerate prefilled syringe or ampule at 2 to 8 degrees C; add entire contents of syringe or ampule to the vial and shake until completely dissolved, resulting in a clear, colorless solution; administer immediately; stable after reconstitution for 24 hours at 30 degrees C
    • administer IM, preferably into the deltoid muscle, or into the anterolateral thigh in children 12 to 23 months of age
